member.name: M:uLobby.AccountManager.Master.UpdateAccount(uLobby.IAccount,uLobby.AccountUpdate)
member.summary: Updates the fields of an account.
member.remarks: After updating an account, any account instances that were fetched before the update may contain old information. It is up to you to make sure that you use up-to-date account instances containing the new information. However, since the ID can never be changed, old instances can still be used for referring to the correct account.
member.param: The account to update.
The update to apply to the account.
member.returns: A request representing this operation, that upon successful completion contains the updated account.

member.name: M:uLobby.FriendManager.Master.AcceptFriendInvitation(uLobby.FriendInvitation)
member.summary: Accepts a friend invitation lobby-side.

remarks.para: Accepting a friend invitation will add both accounts as friends of each other, and remove the friend invitation from the recipient's list of received invitations.

If the friend invitation was successfully accepted, the event will be raised in the peer logged in to the inviter account. Furthermore, the event will be raised in the peers logged in to the inviter and recipient accounts.

member.param: The friend invitation to accept.
member.returns: A request representing this operation.

member.name: M:uLobby.FriendManager.Master.DeclineFriendInvitation(uLobby.FriendInvitation)
member.summary: Declines a friend invitation lobby-side.

remarks.para: Declining a friend invitation will remove it from the recipient's list of received invitations.
If the friend invitation was successfully declined, the event will be raised in the peer logged in to the inviter account.

member.param: The friend invitation to decline.
member.returns: A request representing this operation.

member.name: P:uLobby.FriendManager.Master.isAuthoritative
member.summary: Sets or gets whether the friend manager is authoritative.
member.remarks: When the friend manager is authoritative, requests sent from clients using the client-side API will be ignored. Only the lobby-side API of this class can then be used for managing friends.

member.name: T:uLobby.FriendList
member.summary: Represents the friend list of an account.

remarks.para: This class is used for getting the list of friends of an account, and its received friend invitations.
Client-side, instances of this class remain updated when the actual friend list changes. On the lobby side they do not, however, so you will have to refetch the friend list to get the latest state.

member.name: T:uLobby.IAccountOperations
member.summary: This interface contains all methods related to storing, retrieving and finding accounts and information related to them.

member.name: M:uLobby.IAccountOperations.AddAccountCoroutine(uLobby.AccountRecord,uLobby.Request{uLobby.AccountRecord})
member.summary: Adds an account to the database. This is by defnition a new account and is used in Register method of the account manager module.
member.param: The containing all information about the account to be stored.
The that you can throw exceptions in if you fail to store the account
member.remarks: You don't have to use all of the information provided in the , For example you can use your own/database's id generation mechanism instead of using the generated ID. The ID is generated in another method of your own but based on your database system you might want to let it do the job.

member.name: M:uLobby.IAccountOperations.GetAccountCoroutine(uLobby.AccountID,System.String,System.Boolean,uLobby.Request{uLobby.Account})
member.summary: This method should find and return the account which has the id or name provided. It should first see if the account with the id available and if the id was null, then it should check for the account with the name to see if it's available or not. You should not implement a method which returns an account with both name and id matched cause the way we use it will cause it to always return nothing.
member.param: The id of the account which should be returned
Name of the account which should be retrieved.
If this is true then if you did not find the account, an exception should be thrown
The request which you should put the found account in its result

member.name: M:uLobby.IAccountOperations.GetAccountRecordCoroutine(uLobby.AccountID,uLobby.Request{uLobby.AccountRecord})
member.summary: This method should return an which contains all of the information regarding the account with the specified ID.
member.param: The which the account owning it should be returned
The request which you the result should be set in it.

member.summary: This method should update the information of the account specified. password and data can be changed and you can check if they've been changed or not using the methods in .

The updated information which you should use to update the account.
The request which can be used for throwing exceptions.

member.name: M:uLobby.IAccountOperations.GetNewAccountIDCoroutine(uLobby.Request{uLobby.AccountID})
member.summary: This method should generate and return a new ID to be used by the account which we want to create.
member.param: The which you should put the result in it.
member.remarks: If you don't want to use the ID generated here when storing the data in then you can create a dummy using a constant string just like the mysql example.

member.name: T:uLobby.IFriendOperations
member.summary: This interface contains all methods related to storage and retrieval of friend lists for uLobby's friend list module. uLobby let's you know of the all friend lists for the friend in question and all of the invitations sent to him/her. AccountIDs for all of them are provided and it's your duty as the implementer to connect s in these to those related to the implementation of the to refer to the same accounts.
member.remarks: We've not implemented account removal in uLobby but if you choose to implement it, keep in mind that you should update these lists inside your database as well.

member.name: M:uLobby.IFriendOperations.GetFriendListRecordCoroutine(uLobby.AccountID,uLobby.Request{uLobby.FriendListRecord})
member.summary: This method should asynchronously retireves the data regarding a user's friends and invitations and create a using them and set it as the result of the request.
member.param: The account which you need to retrieve its friend list and invitation list.
The which you should feel with your results or throw exceptions in it.

member.name: M:uLobby.IFriendOperations.SetFriendListRecordCoroutine(uLobby.AccountID,uLobby.FriendListRecord,uLobby.Request)
member.summary: This method should stores all of the friends and invitations of an account into the storage system for later retrieval.
member.param: The account that you want to store its friends and invitations
The which you can read friends and invitations from.
The that you can throw exceptions in if things go wrong.

member.name: T:uLobby.IStorageManager
member.summary: This interface contains all of the methods and properties related to general functionality and status of the storage system. Things like system's readiness for doing operations and system initialization are define here.

member.name: M:uLobby.IStorageManager.Initialize
member.summary: This method should initializes the storage and retrieval system and tries to make it ready to use.
member.example: In connection based databases it should try to connect to the database, in file bases systems it probably should try to open the file and ...
member.remarks: This method will be called inside the lobby's InitializeLobby method. For many systems you will not implement anything specific in this and just define your own methods in your class for initializing it.

member.name: P:uLobby.IStorageManager.isReadyToUse
member.summary: This property should return that if the storage system is ready to use or not.
member.example: For connection based systems you can make it return true after connection is established, for file based ones you might tell it to return if the file is open or not.
member.remarks: You can always return true if the readiness of the system only will be known when you try to do the main operations. If you connect to your database just before you want to run a query, you can not decide in this method if the DB connection is ready or not.

member.name: T:uLobby.Lobby
member.summary: The entry point of the uLobby API.
member.remarks: This class provides static methods for performing basic lobby tasks, such as initializing a lobby, connecting to it as a client or server, sending RPCs between peers, querying about the lobby state, and more.

member.summary: Disconnects from the network.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.DisconnectImmediate
member.summary: Disconnects immediately from the network.
member.remarks: Immediately closes the network connection without notifying others on the network or giving a chance for outgoing messages to arrive.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.CloseConnection(uLobby.LobbyPeer,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Closes the connection to the specified peer.
member.remarks: Only the lobby can close connections to arbitrary peers. Client-side, only the connection to the lobby can be closed, which is equivalent to disconnecting.
member.param: The peer whose connection will be closed.
Whether to notify the peer that the connection will be closed, or to close the connection immediately.
The time in milliseconds to linger before closing the connection, to allow outgoing messages to arrive.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.InitializeSecurity(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes security for future peers, and optionally current peers. Can only be called lobby-side.

remarks.para: Initializes security in the lobby, meaning that all future peers will be requested to initialize security when connecting to the lobby. If is set to true, security will be initialized for all currently connected peers.
When security is initialized for a peer, all communication between the peer and the lobby is encrypted.

member.param: Whether to initialize security for all currently connected peers.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.InitializeSecurity(uLobby.LobbyPeer)
member.summary: Initializes security for a peer. Can only be called lobby-side.
member.remarks: When security is initialized for a peer, all communication between the peer and the lobby is encrypted.
member.param: The peer to initialize security for.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.UninitializeSecurity(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Uninitializes security for future peers, and optionally current peers. Can only be called lobby-side.

remarks.para: Uninitializes security in the lobby, meaning that future peers will no longer be requested to initialize security when connecting to the lobby. If is set to true, security will be uninitialized for all currently connected peers.

member.param: Whether to uninitialize security for all currently connected peers.

member.name: M:uLobby.Lobby.UninitializeSecurity(uLobby.LobbyPeer)
member.summary: Uninitializes security for a peer. Can only be called lobby-side.
member.param: The peer to uninitialize security for.

member.name: T:uLobby.Lobby.Config
member.summary: Contains configuration parameters for the lobby.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.localIP
member.summary: The local IP endpoint to use for network communication.
member.remarks: This value can be used for selecting which network interface to use for network communication. To have effect it needs to be set before initializing a lobby or connecting to a lobby.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.maximumTransmissionUnit
member.summary: The maximum number of bytes that can be sent in a UDP packet.

remarks.para: Only modify this if you know what you are doing. The default value 1400 has been carefully chosen for optimal speed and throughput in most link layers in IP networks. The value 1400 will ensure that UDP packets with uLobby traffic (data and all headers) fit into a single Ethernet frame (1500 max) and thus the packet loss risk will be minimal for each UDP packet.
This value can be set independently for the local and remote host.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.timeBetweenPings
member.summary: The number of seconds between ping messages.

remarks.para: The two hosts of a connection routinely send ping messages to the other side to check that the connection is still alive. This value controls how often the local host sends a ping message to the remote host. The default value is 10 seconds.
This value can be set independently for the local and remote host.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.timeoutDelay
member.summary: The number of seconds before a connection times out.

remarks.para: This value controls the delay before a connection times out. When no message has been received from the remote host for a period longer than this delay, the connection is closed. The default value is 60 seconds.
This value can be set independently for the local and remote host.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.handshakeRetriesMaxCount
member.summary: The maximum number of reattempts to connect to the remote host before giving up.

remarks.para: When the first attempt to connect to a remote host fails, the local host will wait for seconds and then attempt to connect again. This value controls how many such reattempts will be made. The default value is 5 reattempts.
This value only has meaning for servers and clients.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.handshakeRetryDelay
member.summary: The time between successive connection reattempts.

remarks.para: When the first attempt to connect to a remote host fails, the local host will perform reattempts at establishing the connection. This value controls for how long it will wait between each reattempt. The default value is 2.5 seconds.
This value only has meaning for servers and clients.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.receiveBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the buffer used for receiving messages, in bytes.

member.name: P:uLobby.Lobby.Config.sendBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the buffer used for sending messages, in bytes.

member.name: T:uLobby.LobbyMessageFlags
member.summary: Options used for customizing various properties of RPCs.

remarks.para: If the flag is set, the RPC will be sent on an unreliable channel, meaning that it may not reach the target. If this flag is not set, the RPC will be sent reliably and is guaranteed to reach its target.

If the flag is set, the RPC will never be encrypted, even if security has been initialized for the connection. This can be used for increasing performance when sending messages that do not need to be encrypted.

Normally, RPCs are type safe, meaning that the RPC contains type information for every argument in the RPC. If there is a mismatch between the types stored in the RPC and the arguments of the method implementing the RPC, uLobby will see this and log an error. To save bandwidth you can specify the flag, which means no type information will be stored per argument. However, if an argument mismatch occurs this will not be detected and will most likely result in a deserialization error.

member.name: F:uLobby.LobbyMessageFlags.Normal
member.summary: The default configuration. The RPC will be reliable, type safe and encrypted (if security is initialized).

member.name: F:uLobby.LobbyMessageFlags.Unreliable
member.summary: The RPC will be sent on an unreliable channel.

member.name: F:uLobby.LobbyMessageFlags.Unencrypted
member.summary: The RPC will be sent unencrypted.

member.name: F:uLobby.LobbyMessageFlags.TypeUnsafe
member.summary: The RPC will not contain type information for arguments.

member.name: T:uLobby.Log
member.summary: Class for configuring uLink logging.
member.remarks: The best way to get started with logging in uLink is to use the Editor menu: uLink - Edit Settings. There it is possbile to configure logging level per category and use the generated output to debug most problems. By default the log messages are written to the Unity console window in the editor or the log file output_log.txt when running a build outside the editor. Use this class to go one step further and control the log settings in your own code. Also use it to replace the 4 public Writers with your own faster implementations: , , , . with your own implementations it is possible to log events to screen or file(s) or database or whatever you like. Finally, it is possible to add your own logging categories like Trading, Cheating attempts or Level loding and set the log level individually for these categories.

member.name: M:uLobby.Log.Debug(uLobby.LogFlags,System.Object[])
member.summary: Sends a log message to the delegate if the log level for the specifed categories (flags) are set by either or .
member.param: The categories this log message belongs to
The objects that are to be concatenated to a log message if the debug log level for the flags is set
member.example:
Example code for writing a message like "The server has now received 88 Fire RPCs from player Paul55".
uLink.NetworkLog.Debug(uLink.NetworkLogFlags.Server, "The server has now received ", numberOfFireRPCs, " Fire RPCs from player ", playerName);
member.remarks: Please note that it is important to NOT use string concatenation with + to compose the log message. Instead send the objects individually just like the example code provided here. Otherwise you will lose performace. The concatenation would be executed even if the log level for the flags are turned off, and that is a waste of CPU resources.

member.name: T:uLobby.Request
member.summary: Represents an asynchronous lobby request.

remarks.para: This class is returned by many lobby operations that are asynchronous in their nature. For example, operations that need to work with the database are typically asynchronous and therefore return instances of this class.
You can use this class to keep track of operations, wait for them to finish, and check their status.
